thread.title: Rutgers running back rotation: Who's up vs. Indiana?
thread.title_full: Rutgers running back rotation: Who's up vs. Indiana?

title: Rutgers running back rotation: Who's up vs. Indiana?
text:
Rutgers running back rotation: Who's up vs. Indiana? Ryan Dunleavy , @rydunleavy 2:38 p.m. EDT October 17, 2015 Buy Photo Halfback Josh Hicks has led Rutgers in rushing in four of the first five games. (Photo: Jason Towlen/Staff Photographer) Buy Photo CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
BLOOMINGTON, Ind. - Who’s it going to be today? 
The Rutgers halfback-by-committee approach can be unpredictable – as best evidenced last week when Paul James ripped off a season-long 72-yard run in the first quarter against Michigan State and only got one more carry the rest of the way. 
“You never know how it’s going to work out with the series or how they go,” James said. “Sometimes you’re going to draw the short straw, and that’s just how it happened.” 
James has started all five games but the Michigan State game was the only time he led the team in rushing – despite just two carries. He has 243 yards for the season. 
Josh Hicks led the team in rushing in each of the first four games and has a team-high 396 yards, while Robert Martin is nipping at his heels with 313 rushing yards. 
No doubt that Indiana, which hosts Rutgers at 3:30 p.m., remembers Hicks and Martin after their joint coming-out party when the teams met a season ago. 
Martin finished with 83 yards and three touchdowns while Hicks totaled 114 and a score. 
“Their defense definitely looks a lot better than last year,” Martin said. “They are a more solid team and they play with a lot of energy. I watched the game when they played Ohio State. They played them with good energy. I think it’s going to be a good game and I’m looking forward to it.” 
Martin was the feature back on the 16-play 91-yard drive to tie the score against Michigan State with four minutes remaining. 
The sophomore carried nine times, including on first-and-goal from the 9-yard line, when he gained five but was tripped up by an on-the-ground tackler wrestling with offensive lineman Chris Muller. Martin saw the huge hole in front of him. 
“I try to hit it in there and hit the hole hard because I know they were coming down the hill fast so I tried to get what I could get,” Martin said. 
“I definitely saw (the end zone) but then I saw my lineman and a defensive end on the ground so I tried to squeeze through. And I think he hit my legs when I tried to squeeze through.”
